para.para.body: Suppose \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}a_n converges absolutely. If \sigma\from \NNr\to \NNr is a bijection, then
We know that \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}a_n = L\in\RNr , and we need to show that the sequence of partial sums
converges to L as well. To see this, suppose \varepsilon > 0 is given. Choose N\in\NNr such that
Then set K:=\max\Set{ \sigma(0),\dots ,\sigma(N) } \geq N . For arbitrary k\geq 0 , we then find

math.display.latex: \begin{array}{rcl} \Abs{ {\color{red} L}\ -\ A_{K+k} } & = & \Abs{ {\color{red} \left(\sum_{n=0}^{N} a_n\ +\ \sum_{n=N+1}^{\infty} a_n\right)}\ -\ {\color{blue} \sum_{n=0}^{K+k}a_{\sigma_n} } } \\ & = & \Abs{ {\color{red} \left(\sum_{n=0}^{N} a_n\ +\ \sum_{n=N+1}^{\infty} a_n\right)}\ -\ {\color{blue} \left( \sum_{n=0}^{N} a_n\ +\ \sum_{n=N+1}^{K+k} a_{t_n} \right) } } \\ & = & \Abs{ \sum_{n=N+1} a_n\ -\ \sum_{n=N+1}^{K+k} a_{t_n} } \\ & \leq & \underset{\leftarrow\hfill <\ \varepsilon/2 \hfill \to}{ \sum_{n=N+1}^{\infty} \Abs{a_n} }\ +\ \underset{\leftarrow\hfill <\ \varepsilon/2\ \hfill \to }{ \sum_{n=N+1}^{K+k} \Abs{a_{t_n}} } \\ & < & \varepsilon \end{array}

para.para.body: In the computation above, t_n \geq N+1 for n\geq N+1 . This was to be shown.
